awd_titl_txt: Biomechanical Simulations of Progressing Osteoarthritis to Advance Understanding and Therapies
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this project is to understand the influence of intra-tissue stress distributions on the progression of osteoarthritis (OA) in human cartilage by leveraging new mechanical and imaging experiments, novel simulations of evolving virtual human cartilage in vivo, and multiple images of the knee from the NIH-funded Osteoarthritis Initiative (OAI) database. OA is a disease of the synovial joint, with degeneration and loss of articular cartilage as one hallmark change. Mechanical stresses play a key role in the destructive evolution of the disease. Both overloading (e.g. trauma) and reduced loading (e.g. immobilization) of cartilage induce molecular and microstructural changes that lead to mechanical softening, fibrillation, and erosion. Crucially, there is currently no direct method to correlate spatially resolved intra-tissue stresses with progression of OA in individual patients.  Events with the Connecticut  Science Center's Women in Science Initiative will spark STEM interest in female middle school students. High school, undergraduate and graduate students will perform new experiments and establish simulations.

The primary hypothesis is that intra-tissue stresses (e.g. maximum shear stresses) will more strongly correlate with structurally defined OA progression measured by changes in both the network of collagen fibers (organization and density) and gross tissue volume, than with corresponding strains. Objective 1 establishes chemo-biomechanical constitutive relations for evolving OA ex vivo by measuring the large-shear stress-strain response of OA human cartilage; imaging the corresponding cell viability, composition, and microstructure; establishing functions describing the turnover of structurally significant cartilage constituents; and incorporating these within a custom simulation framework. Objective 2 establishes and validates simulations of evolving virtual human cartilage in vivo by establishing patient-specific models using the OAI data; training simulations to produce measured time-course outcomes; performing sensitivity and statistical analyses; and performing validation studies using additional OAI patients. The studies will link physical activity, and the resulting mechanical stimuli, to progression of OA and loss of cartilage function.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: We established a virtual cartilage modeling framework and calibrated this, in part, on our comprehensive experimental exploration into osteoarthritis (OA) – all aimed at understanding of human articular cartilage in health and disease. Examining mechanical changes during OA progression, our work unveils a shift in cartilage properties, indicating potential early diagnostic markers. We delve into shear strain patterns, identifying sensitive biomarkers for early OA detection. By quantifying changes in collagen morphology, we contribute to a mechanistic understanding of OA progression. Investigating cellular responses to low-energy impact loading sheds light on previously unnoticed mechanotransductive sensitivity in chondrocytes. Additionally, we discuss the role of finite element modeling in cartilage analysis, democratize access to convolutional neural networks (CNN) for cartilage segmentation, and introduce a virtual cartilage modeling framework for computational investigations into OA causes and progression.

Evolving Mechanical Properties in OA: In examining the evolution of articular cartilage properties during OA, our work transcends conventional boundaries. By conducting tests on specimens from individuals undergoing total knee arthroplasty (TKA), we reveal a nuanced picture of cartilage evolution. The observed reduction in stiffness, nonlinearities, and energy dissipation as OA advances suggests a potential shift in energy dissipation as an early diagnostic marker for OA. Even cartilage that appears normal exhibits a 50% reduction in energy dissipation compared to healthy load-bearing cartilage, emphasizing the subtleties of early OA detection.

Shear Strain Patterns as Biomarkers: Our investigation into shear strain patterns during early-stage OA uncovers crucial insights. Through displacement-driven, large-strain shear tests on osteoarthritic human cartilage specimens, we identify three general shapes in through-thickness shear strain curves. The notable changes in the deep zone during OA progression indicate that through-thickness patterns of shear strain could serve as sensitive biomarkers for the early detection of OA.

Collagen Morphology in Early OA: Quantifying zone-specific evolution in collagen morphology becomes paramount in understanding OA progression. Employing advanced techniques like transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and custom image analyses, we visualize and quantify changes in collagen fiber orientation, dispersion, and diameter. The increased dispersion in the alignment of collagen fibers during early OA progression, particularly in the superficial and deep zones, provides quantitative data crucial for understanding the disease and identifying potential biomarkers.

Cellular Responses to Low-Energy Impact: Our investigation into the longitudinal effects of low-energy impact loading on chondrocyte behavior reveals a previously unnoticed mechano-transductive sensitivity. In an in vitro study, we assess full-thickness osteochondral plugs of bovine cartilage subjected to single, uniaxial unconfined impact loads. Surprisingly, low-energy impacts stimulate time-dependent anabolic responses in the superficial zone but catabolic responses in the middle and deep zones. Impact energy density emerges as a consistent predictor of cell responses, offering new insights into the nuanced behavior of chondrocytes under mechanical stress.

Role of Finite Element Modeling: A review within our work underscores the significance of finite element (FE) modeling in cartilage analysis. We emphasize the importance of accurate constitutive models for cartilage in developing patient-specific clinical tools, investigating fundamental research questions, assessing individual patients, and advancing tissue engineering. This discussion lays the foundation for sophisticated models necessary to precisely capture the complexity of cartilage mechanics.

Democratizing Access to CNNs for Cartilage Segmentation: Addressing practical challenges in cartilage segmentation in magnetic resonance images (MRIs) required to create patient-specific finite element models, we present an accessible implementation of convolutional neural networks (CNN). This user-friendly approach democratizes access to CNNs for automated segmentation of cartilage volumes, providing a time-efficient and reliable alternative to manual delineation. The method allows clinical personnel to create their own DL models without extensive expertise or specific infrastructure.

Virtual Cartilage Modeling Framework: Our groundbreaking virtual cartilage modeling framework integrates time-dependent, chemo-mechano-biologically induced turnover of key constituents in cartilage. Simulating the loss of cartilage during immobilization and overloading, this flexible platform facilitates computational investigations into the intricate interplay of mechanical stimuli, biochemical signaling, and cartilage function in OA progression. This innovative framework lays the groundwork for future studies aiming to unravel the complex causes, devise effective treatments, and explore preventive strategies for OA.

Impact Statement: Osteoarthritis (OA) affects more than 26.9 million individuals in the United States, causing pain, functional limitations, lost earnings, and depression. Despite its widespread impact, the cause and progression of OA remain poorly understood. Mechanics play a pivotal role in OA, with both overloading (e.g., trauma) and reduced loading (e.g., immobilization) inducing detrimental molecular, morphological, and mechanical changes in cartilage. This project contributed to public health by establishing innovative biomechanical tools that enhance current understanding of disease progression in cartilage and other soft tissues.

Workforce Development: One PhD student honed skills in mechanical testing of soft tissues, along with acquiring computational expertise. A Post-Doc and another PhD student developed skills in theoretical and numerical mechanics, and proficiency in software development. Notably, around 20 undergraduate students engaged in related research, gaining valuable experience in mechanical testing and image analyses.
